competitiveness the first question we
really had to address for ourselves was
what do we mean by competitiveness how
do we tell whether a country is
competitive and here there's actually a
lot of confusion that's really hurt the
public debate it's actually affected a
lot of us in business and the way we've
reacted to this issue so as you see here
we believe that competiveness is defined
as the simultaneous ability to achieve
two things the u.s. is competitive if
us-based companies can compete
successfully in international markets
that's kind of intuitive we understand
that but there's another part the u.s.
is competitive if we can do that while
simultaneously maintaining and improving
the standard of living for the average
American having companies succeed while
wages fall and jobs get caught and our
currency to values that's not a sign of
competitiveness that's a sign that we're
not competitive conversely if workers do
well but American companies can no
longer compete that's not victory either
how do we solve this equation of
competitive companies and prosperous
citizens the only way we can solve that
equation is by being highly productive
we have to be a highly productive
location in which to do business to
justify and support the high wages that
we want to earn and sustain and improve
over time and it's this ability to be
productive that has to be the central
focus of all of our economic policy just
creating jobs is the wrong way to look
at it we have to be competitive and if
we can think this way and behave this

other countries in the world many

many countries can improve their

those jobs have been in construction and

in government but not in those
businesses where we actually have to
compete something has gone wrong with
the fundamentals of the American economy
started well before this 2007 2008

in particular wages have been stagnated

for our citizens that has not been true
for some time now i disturbing a sign
and finally and there's more we could
cover the participation of Americans in

ninety-seven I think is the peak of this

others like them convinced us on the

we can thank you tonight by sharing some

three things first that the u.s. faces a
deepening challenge to its
competitiveness to get at this we went
right back to the definition that Mike
identified before and we asked two key
questions in three years time
you think that firms in the US will be
more or less able to succeed in the
global economy and in three years time
we'll US firms be more or less able to
pay workers well and the vast majority
of our respondents 71 percent said that
on one or both of these dimensions of
competitiveness the US would be worse
off in three years in fact when we focus
just a respondent from the New York area
the pessimism deepens a little bit the
figure rises to seventy-three percent
respondents were worried about both US
firms and US workers but on balance were
more concerned about workers and firms
and that makes some sense because when
faced with global competition firms have
fairly good alternatives they can trim

innovate they can move abroad workers
often have fewer and far worse
alternatives second our respondents
shared with us their personal
experiences in firm location choices
which are important indicator of us
competiveness it turns out that more
than 1700 of our respondents had

potentially moving them to other
countries some we're about or insuring
taking activities currently in other
countries potentially moving them to
America and others were about setting up
new activities that might go into the US
the respondents noted a few troubling

activity is out of the u.s. we sometimes
read these days hopeful stories about
activities that are returning to America
we did see that in our survey but by far
the more dominant flow was outward in
fact HBS Alam based in the u.s. is three
times more likely to be considering
moving activity out of the US then an HP
s-salam based outside the US is likely
to be thinking about moving something
into the u.s. second when those

thousand of those decisions were about
potentially offshoring activities once
those decisions were resolved five times
out of six the activity did move out of
the
overall the US won only one out of three
of the decisions for which it was a

are moving out our low value-added or
small activities and things moving into
the US or being set up to your fresh are
you know larger facilities with high-end

in fact the evidence we find is very
much to the contrary the high-end stuff

optimistic and felt good about the

could ask respondents about 17 elements

first how is the u.s. doing today

and second how is the u.s. doing in

in we got some good news right some good

right our system for entrepreneurship

know if that matrix describes where we

leave the question of where we might go

are many many factors in play here but I

1980s when changes in geopolitics and

business that the geographic options
open to managers expand dramatically at
the same time certain changes in
governance in America increase the focus
many managers and some politicians on
the the near term time horizon shorten
and the combination of broaden

evitable that business people in the US

individual area and the ensuing
globalization has had enormous positive

are also some troubling challenges that

is that the connections between
companies and the communities in which
they operate which were naturally there
when companies were confined
geographically those connections start
to fade and with them the public goods
in which firms had steadily invested a
second problem that brings that this
brings on is that it brings enormous
pressure on the middle costs of our

trade and sectors of the economy follow
meanwhile if you are the upper end of

how do we respond to increasing
pressures on the middle class one

unfortunately I think we've seen less of

and we want you to consume particularly

your retirement promises like the

our real focus in this project is really

by and large American companies have
done okay there in many respects but

us competitiveness in way by that i mean

an innovative contributing to the

is not about charity or being

sustainably in the long run letting the

business lose out because failure to

forward the the globalization era that

us in business
about how to think about this issue and
and in the rush to globalization we've

our most fundamental role to our own

there's really two ways that companies

what we would have asked you in the
